en: From the corner of the divan of Persian saddle-bags on which he was lying, smoking, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could just catch the gleam of the honey-sweet and honey-coloured blossoms of a laburnum, whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden of a beauty so flamelike as theirs; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in flight flitted across the long tussore-silk curtains that were stretched in front of the huge window, producing a kind of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pallid, jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ.
es: Lord Henry Wotton, que habÃ­a consumido ya, segÃºn su costumbre, innumerables cigarrillos, vislumbraba, desde el extremo del sofÃ¡ donde estaba tumbado â€”tapizado al estilo de las alfombras persasâ€”, el resplandor de las floraciones de un codeso, de dulzura y color de miel, cuyas ramas estremecidas apenas parecÃ­an capaces de soportar el peso de una belleza tan deslumbrante como la suya; y, de cuando en cuando, las sombras fantÃ¡sticas de pÃ¡jaros en vuelo se deslizaban sobre las largas cortinas de seda india colgadas delante de las inmensas ventanas, produciendo algo asÃ­ como un efecto japonÃ©s, lo que le hacÃ­a pensar en los pintores de Tokyo, de rostros tan pÃ¡lidos como el jade, que, por medio de un arte necesariamente inmÃ³vil, tratan de transmitir la sensaciÃ³n de velocidad y de movimiento. El zumbido obstinado de las abejas, abriÃ©ndose camino entre el alto cÃ©sped sin segar, o dando vueltas con monÃ³tona insistencia en torno a los polvorientos cuernos dorados de las desordenadas madreselvas, parecÃ­an hacer mÃ¡s opresiva la quietud, mientras los ruidos confusos de Londres eran como las notas graves de un Ã³rgano lejano.
es_translation: Lord Henry Wotton, who had already consumed, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, glimpsed, from the end of the sofa where he was lying â€”upholstered in the style of Persian carpetsâ€”, the glow of the blossoms of a broom, sweet and honey-colored, whose trembling branches barely seemed capable of bearing the weight of such dazzling beauty as theirs; and, from time to time, the fantastic shadows of birds in flight slid over the long Indian silk curtains hanging in front of the immense windows, producing something like a Japanese effect, which made him think of the painters of Tokyo, with faces as pale as jade, who, through a necessarily motionless art, try to convey the sensation of speed and movement. The obstinate buzzing of bees, making their way through the tall unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence around the dusty golden horns of the disordered honeysuckles, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive, while the confused noises of London were like the deep notes of a distant organ.

tr_translation: Lord Henry Wotton, who was lying in the corner of the divan adorned with Iranian saddlebags, smoking countless cigarettes as was his habit, could make out the honey-colored, honey-sweet flowers of the yellow wisteria tree from where he was. The tree's trembling branches seemed to struggle under the burden of such flame-like beauty. Occasionally, the shadows of birds, like dreams, would fall upon the long, silken curtains stretched in front of the large window. At first glance, these curtains, which evoked a Japanese atmosphere, reminded Lord Henry of the pale, emerald-faced painters of Tokyo; painters who tried to convey movement and speed through the necessarily static medium of art. The dull hum of bees, either trying to make their way through the tall, uncut grass or circling monotonously around the dusty, gilded horns of the sprawling French marigolds, seemed to make the tranquility of the surroundings all the more tedious. The faint hum of London resembled the bass notes of a distant organ melody.

vi_translation: From the corner of the Persian camel saddlebag-patterned divan on which he habitually lay smoking countless cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could only faintly see the honey-sweet and honey-colored blossoms of a laburnum tree whose trembling branches seemed to struggle under the weight of such a blazing beauty; and occasionally, the strange shadows of birds in flight would flicker across the long tussore silk curtains drawn before the wide window, evoking a sensation somewhat akin to a fleeting Japanese impression, and making him think of the green-faced, yellow-fanged artists in Tokyo, who, through the medium of an inherently static art, had attempted to convey a sense of swiftness and movement. The mournful hum of bees threading through the long, uncut grass, or circling with monotonous persistence around the golden-tipped horns of the overgrown honeysuckle, seemed to make the stillness even more oppressive. The distant roar of London was like the pedal note of a far-off organ.

en: In the centre of the room, clamped to an upright easel, stood the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary personal beauty, and in front of it, some little distance away, was sitting the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance some years ago caused, at the time, such public excitement and gave rise to so many strange conjectures.

In front of it, a little further away, sat the painter of the portrait: Basil Hallward, who had caused quite a stir a few years ago by suddenly disappearing and giving rise to a host of strange speculations.

vi_translation: In the middle of the room, clamped tightly onto an upright easel, was a full-length portrait of a young man with extraordinary personal beauty, and sitting in front of it, a little further away, was the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance a few years ago had caused, at that time, an overwhelming public sensation and generated a myriad of strange speculations.

en: For nearly ten minutes he stood there, motionless, with parted lips and eyes strangely bright. He was dimly conscious that entirely fresh influences were at work within him. Yet they seemed to him to have come really from himself. The few words that Basilâ€™s friend had said to himâ€”words spoken by chance, no doubt, and with wilful paradox in themâ€”had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before, but that he felt was now vibrating and throbbing to curious pulses.

Las pocas palabras que el amigo de Basil le habÃ­a dicho, palabras lanzadas al azar, sin duda, y caprichosamente paradÃ³jicas, habÃ­an tocado alguna cuerda secreta, nunca pulsada anteriormente, pero que sentÃ­a ahora vibrar y palpitar con peculiares estremecimientos.
es_translation: For about ten minutes he remained there, motionless, his lips parted and a strange gleam in his eyes. He was vaguely aware that completely new influences were at work within him, although, it seemed to him, they actually came from himself. The few words that Basil's friend had said to him, words thrown out at random, no doubt, and whimsically paradoxical, had touched some secret chord, never before struck, but which he now felt vibrating and throbbing with peculiar tremors.

tr_translation: He stood there almost motionless for about ten minutes, his lips parted, a strange brightness in his eyes. He vaguely sensed the brand-new stirrings within him, yet they seemed to have come from within himself. en: Dorian Gray listened, open-eyed and wondering. The spray of lilac fell from his hand upon the gravel. A furry bee came and buzzed round it for a moment. Then it began to scramble all over the oval stellated globe of the tiny blossoms. He watched it with that strange interest in trivial things that we try to develop when things of high import make us afraid, or when we are stirred by some new emotion for which we cannot find expression, or when some thought that terrifies us lays sudden siege to the brain and calls on us to yield. After a time the bee flew away. He saw it creeping into the stained trumpet of a Tyrian convolvulus. The flower seemed to quiver, and then swayed gently to and fro.
es: Dorian Gray escuchaba, los ojos muy abiertos, asombrado. El ramillete de lilas se le cayÃ³ al suelo. Una sedosa abeja zumbÃ³ a su alrededor por un instante. Dorian Gray la observÃ³ con el extraÃ±o interÃ©s por las cosas triviales que tratamos de fomentar cuando las mÃ¡s importantes nos asustan, o cuando nos embarga alguna nueva emociÃ³n que no sabemos expresar, o cuando alguna idea que nos aterra pone repentino sitio a la mente y exige nuestra rendiciÃ³n. Al cabo de algÃºn tiempo la abeja alzÃ³ el vuelo. Dorian Gray la vio introducirse en la campanilla de una enredadera. La flor pareciÃ³ estremecerse y luego se balanceÃ³ suavemente hacia adelante y hacia atrÃ¡s.
es_translation: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide open, astonished. The bouquet of lilacs fell to the ground. A silky bee buzzed around him for a moment. Then it began to climb laboriously over the star-shaped globes of each flower. Dorian Gray watched it with the strange interest in trivial things that we try to cultivate when the more important ones frighten us, or when we are overwhelmed by some new emotion that we do not know how to express, or when some idea that terrifies us suddenly besieges the mind and demands our surrender. After some time, the bee took flight. Dorian Gray saw it enter the bell of a vine flower. The flower seemed to shudder and then gently swayed back and forth.

tr_translation: Dorian opened his eyes, listening in a dazed and bewildered manner. The lilac in his hand fell onto the pebbles on the ground. A fuzzy bee came and buzzed over the lilac for a moment. Then it climbed onto the tuft of star-shaped tiny flowers. Dorian watched the bee with that strange interest we try to feel towards insignificant things when important things frighten us, when a brand-new feeling we cannot name stirs within us, or when a thought that terrifies us suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. He saw the bee burrow into the bright-colored trumpet of a purple laughing flower. The flower seemed to shiver slightly, then began to gently sway back and forth.

vi_translation: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide with astonishment. The lilac branch fell from his hand onto the grass. A fuzzy bee flew over and buzzed around for a moment. Then it began to crawl all over the star-speckled oval gourd. He watched it with that strange fascination we often show for trivial things when important matters frighten us, or when we are distracted by some new emotion we cannot find words to express, or when some terrifying idea suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. A moment later, the bee flew away. He watched it crawl into the tarnished trumpet of a royal purple morning glory. The flower seemed to tremble, then gently sway.

en: â€œIt is an interesting question,â€ said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the ladâ€™s unconscious egotism, â€œan extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves, and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored meâ€”there have not been very many, but there have been someâ€”have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.â€
es: â€”Es un caso interesante â€”dijo lord Henry, que encontraba un placer sutil enjugar con el egoÃ­smo inconsciente de su joven amigoâ€”; un caso sumamente interesante. Creo que la verdadera explicaciÃ³n es Ã©sta: sucede con frecuencia que las tragedias reales de la vida ocurren de una manera tan poco artÃ­stica que nos hieren por lo crudo de su violencia, por su absoluta incoherencia, su absurda ausencia de significado, su completa falta de estilo. Nos afectan como lo hace la vulgaridad. SÃ³lo nos producen una impresiÃ³n de fuerza bruta, y nos rebelamos contra eso. A veces, sin embargo, cruza nuestras vidas una tragedia que posee elementos de belleza artÃ­stica. Si esos elementos de belleza son reales, todo el conjunto apela a nuestro sentido del efecto dramÃ¡tico. De repente descubrimos que ya no somos los actores, sino los espectadores de la obra. O que somos mÃ¡s bien las dos cosas. Nos observamos, y el mero asombro del espectÃ¡culo nos seduce. En el caso presente, Â¿quÃ© es lo que ha sucedido en realidad? Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustarÃ­a haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sÃ­ algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo despuÃ©s de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mÃ­. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. Â¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! Â¡QuÃ© cosa mÃ¡s espantosa! Â¡Y quÃ© total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.
es_translation: â€”It is an interesting case â€”said Lord Henry, who found a subtle pleasure in playing with the unconscious selfishness of his young friendâ€”; a most interesting case. I believe the true explanation is this: it often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an unartistic manner that they wound us by the rawness of their violence, by their absolute incoherence, their absurd lack of meaning, their complete lack of style. They affect us as vulgarity does. They only leave us with an impression of brute force, and we rebel against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy crosses our lives that possesses elements of artistic beauty. If those elements of beauty are real, the entire ensemble appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we discover that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather that we are both things. We observe ourselves, and the mere wonder of the spectacle seduces us. In the present case, what has really happened? Someone has killed themselves for love of you. I would have liked to have had such an experience once. It would have made me fall in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me (there have not been many, but a few), have always insisted on continuing to live after I stopped loving them and they stopped loving me. They have become corpulent and tedious, and when I meet them, they immediately dive into memories. Ah, that terrible memory of women! What a dreadful thing! And what total intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colors of life, but never remember the details. The details are always vulgar.

NasÄ±l katÄ±ksÄ±z bir zihin yosunlaÅŸmasÄ±nÄ± ortaya vurur! Ä°nsan yaÅŸamÄ±n rengini emmeli de ayrÄ±ntÄ±larÄ±nÄ± asla hatÄ±rlamamalÄ±. AyrÄ±ntÄ±lar her zaman avam iÅŸidir.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, who took great and secret pleasure in provoking the young man's unconscious selfishness, said, "This is an interesting problem, extremely interesting." " It seems to me that the real explanation is this: Often, the real tragedies of life are so far removed from the standards of art that they hurt us with their crude violence, their inconsistencies, the absurdity of their lack of meaning, their lack of elegance and grace. They affect us much like a crowd does. They leave us with an impression of pure brute force, and we rebel against it. On the other hand, occasionally, a tragedy with elements of artistic beauty enters our lives. If these elements of beauty are genuine, the event affects us directly, in terms of its dramatic structure. Suddenly, we find that we are no longer actors, but spectators of the play. Or rather, we are both actors and spectators. We watch ourselves and get carried away by the extraordinariness of the spectacle. So what has really happened in this event? A girl has killed herself for your love. I wish I had experienced something like that. It would have made me fall in love with love for a lifetime. The people who adored me...though they were not many in number...always insisted on surviving long after the interest I had in them or they had in me had faded. They became fat and tiresome people. Whenever we met, they immediately started to revive old memories. Ah, the terrible memory of a woman! What a dreadful thing it is! How it reveals the pure mossiness of the mind! One should absorb the color of life but never remember its details. Details are always the business of the vulgar."

vi_translation: â€œThat is an interesting question,â€ Lord Henry said, finding a refined pleasure in playing with the unconscious selfishness of the young man â€” â€œa very interesting question. I think the correct explanation is this. It often happens that the real tragedies in life occur in such an anti-artistic manner that they hurt us with their brutal aggression, absolute disjointedness, absurd senselessness, and lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of absolute malicious power, and we resist them. However, sometimes, a tragedy with beautiful artistic elements intersects our lives. If these beautiful elements are real, then the whole affair easily captivates our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer actors, but the audience of the play. Or rather, we are both. We watch ourselves, and it is the very surprise of this performance that fascinates us. In the current situation, what has actually happened? Someone has committed suicide because they loved you. I wish I could have such an experience sometime. It would make me love love for the rest of my life. The people who have been infatuated with me â€” not many, but there have been some â€” always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they for me. They fade away, become dull, and when I meet them again, they immediately drift into memory. That dreadful memory of women! How terrifying it is! And how it reveals a state of complete intellectual dullness! We should absorb the colors of life, but never remember its details. The details are always vulgar.â€

en: As the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked round the room. His eye fell on a large, purple satin coverlet heavily embroidered with gold, a splendid piece of late seventeenth-century Venetian work that his grandfather had found in a convent near Bologna. Yes, that would serve to wrap the dreadful thing in. It had perhaps served often as a pall for the dead. Now it was to hide something that had a corruption of its own, worse than the corruption of death itselfâ€”something that would breed horrors and yet would never die. What the worm was to the corpse, his sins would be to the painted image on the canvas. They would mar its beauty and eat away its grace. They would defile it and make it shameful. And yet the thing would still live on. It would be always alive.
es: Al cerrarse la puerta, Dorian se guardÃ³ la llave en el bolsillo y recorriÃ³ la biblioteca con la mirada. Sus ojos se detuvieron en un amplio cubrecama de satÃ©n morado con bordados en oro que su abuelo habÃ­a encontrado en un convento prÃ³ximo a Bolonia. SÃ­; servirÃ­a para envolver el horrible lienzo. QuizÃ¡s se habÃ­a utilizado mÃ¡s de una vez como mortaja. Ahora tendrÃ­a que ocultar algo con una corrupciÃ³n peculiar, peor que la de los muertos: algo que engendrarÃ­a horrores sin por ello morir nunca. Lo que los gusanos eran para el cadÃ¡ver, serÃ­an sus pecados para la imagen pintada en el lienzo, destruyendo su apostura y devorando su gracia. Lo mancharÃ­an, convirtiÃ©ndolo en algo vergonzoso. Y sin embargo aquella cosa seguirÃ­a viva, vivirÃ­a siempre.
es_translation: As the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and scanned the library with his eyes. His eyes stopped on a large purple satin bedspread with gold embroidery that his grandfather had found in a convent near Bologna. Yes; it would serve to wrap the horrible canvas. Perhaps it had been used more than once as a shroud. Now it would have to hide something with a peculiar corruption, worse than that of the dead: something that would spawn horrors without ever dying. What worms were to the corpse, his sins would be to the image painted on the canvas, destroying its comeliness and devouring its grace. They would stain it, turning it into something shameful. And yet that thing would remain alive, it would live forever.

tr_translation: When the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked around. A heavy, gold-embroidered, wide, purple satin cover caught his eye. This cover, a magnificent Venetian embroidery from the late seventeenth century, had been found by his grandfather in a monastery near Bologna. Yes, it was suitable to cover that dreadful thing. Perhaps it had generally been used to cover a corpse. Now it would serve to hide something that carried its own kind of decay; something that carried a decay worse than death's decay, something that continually spawned horrors yet never died. What worms and maggots are to a corpse in the ground, Dorian's sins would be to the painted image on the canvas. Sins would mar this image's beauty, gnaw at its delicacy. They would defile this image, turn it into something obscene. But the portrait would still continue to live. It would always remain alive.

vi_translation: When the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked around the room. His eyes noticed a large satin bedspread, richly embroidered in gold, a splendid work from late seventeenth-century Venice that his grandfather had found in a nunnery near Bologna. Yes, it would be used to wrap that horrible thing. It might have once been frequently used as a shroud for the dead. Now it concealed something with its own decay, worse than the decay of death itself â€” something that would produce fears but never die. What worms do to a corpse, so would his sins do to the image painted on the canvas. They would mar its beauty, consume its grace. They would defile it, make it shameful. Yet it would continue to live. It would live on forever.

en: Yes: there was to be, as Lord Henry had prophesied, a new Hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having, in our own day, its curious revival. It was to have its service of the intellect, certainly, yet it was never to accept any theory or system that would involve the sacrifice of any mode of passionate experience. Its aim, indeed, was to be experience itself, and not the fruits of experience, sweet or bitter as they might be. Of the asceticism that deadens the senses, as of the vulgar profligacy that dulls them, it was to know nothing. But it was to teach man to concentrate himself upon the moments of a life that is itself but a moment.
es: SÃ­; tenÃ­a que haber, como lord Henry habÃ­a profetizado, un nuevo hedonismo que recreara la vida, que la salvara de ese puritanismo tosco y violento que estÃ¡ teniendo en nuestra Ã©poca un extraÃ±o renacimiento. Un hedonismo que utilizarÃ­a sin duda los servicios de la inteligencia, pero sin aceptar teorÃ­a o sistema alguno que implicara el sacrificio de cualquier modalidad de experiencia apasionada. Su objetivo, efectivamente, era la experiencia misma y no los frutos de la experiencia, tanto dulces como amargos. PrescindirÃ­a del ascetismo que sofoca los sentidos y de la vulgar desvergÃ¼enza que los embota. Pero enseÃ±arÃ­a al ser humano a concentrarse en los instantes singulares de una vida que no es en sÃ­ misma mÃ¡s que un instante.
es_translation: Yes; there had to be, as Lord Henry had prophesied, a new hedonism that would recreate life, that would save it from that coarse and violent puritanism that is having a strange resurgence in our era. A hedonism that would undoubtedly use the services of intelligence, but without accepting any theory or system that implied the sacrifice of any form of passionate experience. Its objective, indeed, was the experience itself and not the fruits of the experience, both sweet and bitter. It would dispense with the asceticism that stifles the senses and the vulgar shamelessness that dulls them. But it would teach the human being to concentrate on the singular moments of a life that is in itself nothing more than a moment.

Bu yeni hedonizm sÄ±rasÄ±nda, dÃ¼ÅŸÃ¼nceden yararlanacaktÄ±, doÄŸallÄ±kla. Ne var ki tutku ve heyecanlardan vazgeÃ§ilmesini gerektiren hiÃ§bir kuram ve dÃ¼zen benimsenmeyecekti. Daha doÄŸrusu amacÄ± doÄŸrudan doÄŸruya bu gibi duyularÄ±n yaÅŸanmasÄ± olacaktÄ±, yoksa bu yaÅŸam deneylerinin acÄ± tatlÄ± meyveleri deÄŸil. DuyularÄ± donduran estetizmden de, duyularÄ± kÃ¶relten avam hovardalÄ±ÄŸÄ±ndan da habersiz olacaktÄ± bu akÄ±m. Ä°nsana, kendisi tek bir andan ibaret olan bir yaÅŸamÄ±n anlarÄ± Ã¼stÃ¼nde durmayÄ± Ã¶ÄŸretecekti.
tr_translation: Yes: Just as Lord Henry predicted, a new hedonism would emerge and recreate life anew; it is very strange that it would save life from the harsh, unattractive conservatism that has resurfaced today. During this new hedonism, it would naturally make use of thought. However, no theory or system that required the abandonment of passions and excitements would be adopted. Rather, its purpose would be to directly experience such sensations, not the bittersweet fruits of these life experiences. This movement would be unaware of both the aesthetism that freezes the senses and the vulgar debauchery that dulls them. It would teach people to focus on the moments of a life that consists of a single moment.

vi_translation: Correct: as Lord Henry predicted, a new Hedonism will emerge, capable of rejuvenating life, saving it from the harsh, graceless morality that is strangely reviving in our era. It will certainly seek the aid of intellect; however, it will never accept any theory or system that demands the sacrifice of any form of passionate experience. Its purpose, indeed, is the experience itself, not the fruits of the experience, whether they be sweet or bitter. As for the asceticism that dulls the senses, and the common debauchery that blunts them, it knows nothing. But it teaches man to focus entirely on the moments of a life that, in its essence, is but a moment.

en: Of such insolences and attempted slights he, of course, took no notice, and in the opinion of most people his frank debonair manner, his charming boyish smile, and the infinite grace of that wonderful youth that seemed never to leave him, were in themselves a sufficient answer to the calumnies, for so they termed them, that were circulated about him. It was remarked, however, that some of those who had been most intimate with him appeared, after a time, to shun him. Women who had wildly adored him, and for his sake had braved all social censure and set convention at defiance, were seen to grow pallid with shame or horror if Dorian Gray entered the room.
es: Dorian Gray, por supuesto, no prestaba la menor atenciÃ³n a tales insolencias y desprecios deliberados y, en opiniÃ³n de la mayorÃ­a, su naturalidad y su aire jovial, su encantadora sonrisa adolescente y la gracia infinita de la maravillosa juventud que parecÃ­a no abandonarle nunca, eran por sÃ­ solas respuesta suficiente a las calumnias, porque asÃ­ las calificaba la mayorÃ­a, que circulaban acerca de Ã©l. Se seÃ±alaba, de todos modos, que algunas de las personas con las que habÃ­a tenido un trato mÃ¡s Ã­ntimo parecÃ­an, al cabo de algÃºn tiempo, evitarlo. Mujeres que manifestaron hacia Ã©l una adoraciÃ³n sin limites, que desafiaron por Ã©l la censurÃ³ de la sociedad y que prescindieron de todas las convenciones, palidecÃ­an de vergÃ¼enza y horror si Dorian Gray entraba en el salÃ³n donde se encontraban.
es_translation: Dorian Gray, of course, paid no attention whatsoever to such insolences and deliberate scorns and, in the opinion of most, his naturalness and jovial air, his charming adolescent smile and the infinite grace of the wonderful youth that seemed never to abandon him, were in themselves a sufficient response to the slanders, because that is how most people described them, that circulated about him. It was noted, however, that some of the people with whom he had had a more intimate relationship seemed, after some time, to avoid him. Women who showed towards him an unlimited adoration, who defied society's censure for him and disregarded all conventions, would pale with shame and horror if Dorian Gray entered the room where they were.

The open-hearted, agile, cheerful attitudes, the friendly, childlike smile, and the endless sweetness of that marvelous youth that never faded from him were, in the eyes of many, the most sufficient response to the slanders against him â€“ because they called these rumors slander. On the other hand, it was noticeable that some of those who were most intimate with him started to avoid him after a while. It was observed that women who had fallen madly in love with him, who had faced all the condemnation of society for his sake, and who had defied traditions, turned pale either from shame or horror when he entered the room.

vi_translation: For such deliberate insolence and disdain, he, of course, didn't bother to pay attention, and in the view of most people, his straightforward and generous attitude, his charming boyish smile, and the endless charm of his marvelous youth, which seemed never to leave him, were in themselves a persuasive enough answer to the slanders, as they called them, that continued to spread about him. However, it was clear that some of those who had been closest to him, after a while, began to avoid him. The women who worshipped him madly, defying all high society's criticisms and challenging all conventions for his sake, were seen to turn pale with shame or fear if Dorian Gray entered the room.

en: Yet these whispered scandals only increased in the eyes of many his strange and dangerous charm. His great wealth was a certain element of security. Societyâ€”civilized society, at leastâ€”is never very ready to believe anything to the detriment of those who are both rich and fascinating. It feels instinctively that manners are of more importance than morals, and, in its opinion, the highest respectability is of much less value than the possession of a good chef. And, after all, it is a very poor consolation to be told that the man who has given one a bad dinner, or poor wine, is irreproachable in his private life. Even the cardinal virtues cannot atone for half-cold entrÃ©es, as Lord Henry remarked once, in a discussion on the subject, and there is possibly a good deal to be said for his view. For the canons of good society are, or should be, the same as the canons of art. Form is absolutely essential to it. It should have the dignity of a ceremony, as well as its unreality, and should combine the insincere character of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays delightful to us. Is insincerity such a terrible thing? I think not. It is merely a method by which we can multiply our personalities.

La sociedad, la sociedad civilizada al menos, nunca estÃ¡ muy dispuesta a creer nada en detrimento de quienes son, al mismo tiempo, ricos y fascinantes. Siente, de manera instintiva, que los modales tienen mÃ¡s importancia que la moral y, en su opiniÃ³n, la respetabilidad mÃ¡s acrisolada vale muchÃ­simo menos que la posesiÃ³n de un buen chef. Y, a decir verdad, consuela muy poco saber que la persona que te invita a una cena execrable o que te sirve un vino de mala calidad es irreprochable en su vida privada. Ni siquiera las virtudes cardinales justifican unas entrÃ©es semifrÃ­as, como seÃ±alÃ³ en una ocasiÃ³n lord Henry en un debate sobre aquel tema; y existen sin duda excelentes razones para sostener ese punto de vista. Porque los cÃ¡nones de la buena sociedad son, o deberÃ­an ser, los mismos que los cÃ¡nones del arte. La forma es absolutamente esencial. La vida social debe tener la dignidad de una ceremonia, y tambiÃ©n su irrealidad, y combinar la insinceridad de una comedia romÃ¡ntica con el ingenio y la belleza que la dotan de encanto para nosotros. Â¿Acaso la insinceridad es una cosa tan terrible? No lo creo. Es, sencillamente, un mÃ©todo que nos permite multiplicar nuestras personalidades.
es_translation: Those whispered scandals only served, however, in the eyes of many, to heighten his strange and dangerous charm. His great fortune was, undoubtedly, an element of security. Society, at least civilized society, is never very willing to believe anything to the detriment of those who are, at the same time, rich and fascinating. It feels, instinctively, that manners are more important than morals and, in its opinion, the most unblemished respectability is worth far less than the possession of a good chef. And, to tell the truth, it is very little consolation to know that the person who invites you to an execrable dinner or serves you poor quality wine is irreproachable in their private life. Not even the cardinal virtues justify semi-cold entrÃ©es, as Lord Henry once remarked in a debate on that subject; and there are undoubtedly excellent reasons to support that point of view. Because the canons of good society are, or should be, the same as the canons of art. Form is absolutely essential. Social life should have the dignity of a ceremony, and also its unreality, and combine the insincerity of a romantic comedy with the wit and beauty that endow it with charm for us. Is insincerity such a terrible thing? I don't think so. It is, simply, a method that allows us to multiply our personalities.

tr_translation: The scandals whispered from ear to ear only served to increase his strange, dangerous allure in the eyes of many. His great wealth was also a certain source of security for him. Society, at least the society of civilized nations, is never willing to believe anything said against someone who is both rich, attractive, and interesting. It has an instinctive belief that the rules of courtesy are more important than the rules of morality, and in its view, even the greatest respectability is less important than employing a good chef. After all, what good is it to know that someone who sets a poor table and serves inferior wine is impeccable in their private life? As Lord Henry once said on this subject, not even the highest virtues can atone for the sin of the main course arriving cold at the table! We believe his view is very well-founded. Because the fundamental laws of high society and the fundamental laws of art are one and the same, or should be. Form is an absolutely indispensable element for society. This form must possess the dignity and insubstantiality of a ceremony and combine the artificial nature of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays endearing to us. Is artificiality bad? I don't think so. It is merely a method that allows us to multiply and diversify our personalities.

Sá»± khÃ´ng thÃ nh thá»±c cÃ³ pháº£i lÃ  má»™t thá»© khá»§ng khiáº¿p Ä‘áº¿n váº­y khÃ´ng? TÃ´i nghÄ© lÃ  khÃ´ng. NÃ³ chá»‰ lÃ  cÃ¡ch giÃºp ta cÃ³ thá»ƒ nhÃ¢n cÃ¡ tÃ­nh ta lÃªn nhiá»u láº§n.
vi_translation: However, those scandals only increased, in the eyes of many, his strange and dangerous allure. His great wealth was also a certain safety factor. Society, at least civilized society, is never willing to believe anything that harms those who are both rich and attractive. It instinctively feels that attitude is more important than virtue, and, in its view, the most respectable character is worth far less than having a good chef. And, after all, we are hardly consoled when told that the person who gave us a lousy dinner, or terrible wine, is blameless in their private life. Even warm-hearted kindness cannot redeem a cold appetizer, as Lord Henry once remarked, in a discussion on this subject; and perhaps there is much to be said for his perspective. For the standards of a good society are, or should be, the same as those of art. Form is an absolutely necessary element for it. It should have the solemnity as well as the unreality of a ritual, and should combine the insincerity of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays enjoyable to us. Is insincerity such a terrible thing? I think not. It is merely a way to multiply our personalities.

en: Yet one had ancestors in literature as well as in oneâ€™s own race, nearer perhaps in type and temperament, many of them, and certainly with an influence of which one was more absolutely conscious. There were times when it appeared to Dorian Gray that the whole of history was merely the record of his own life, not as he had lived it in act and circumstance, but as his imagination had created it for him, as it had been in his brain and in his passions. He felt that he had known them all, those strange terrible figures that had passed across the stage of the world and made sin so marvellous and evil so full of subtlety. It seemed to him that in some mysterious way their lives had been his own.
es: Pero tambiÃ©n se tienen antepasados literarios, ademÃ¡s de los de la propia estirpe, muchos de ellos quizÃ¡ mÃ¡s prÃ³ximos por la constituciÃ³n y el temperamento, y con una influencia de la que se era consciente con mucha mayor claridad. HabÃ­a ocasiones en que a Dorian Gray le parecÃ­a que la totalidad de la historia no era mÃ¡s que el relato de su propia vida, no como la habÃ­a vivido en sus acciones y detalles, sino como su imaginaciÃ³n la habÃ­a creado para Ã©l, como habÃ­a existido en su cerebro y en sus pasiones. TenÃ­a la sensaciÃ³n de haberlas conocido a todas, a aquellas extraÃ±as y terribles figuras que habÃ­an atravesado el gran teatro del mundo, haciendo del pecado algo tan maravilloso y del mal algo tan sutil. Le parecÃ­a que, de algÃºn modo misterioso, sus vidas habÃ­an sido tambiÃ©n la suya.
es_translation: But one also has literary ancestors, in addition to those of one's own lineage, many of whom might be closer in constitution and temperament, and with an influence that was much more clearly recognized. There were times when it seemed to Dorian Gray that the entirety of history was nothing more than the story of his own life, not as he had lived it in his actions and details, but as his imagination had created it for him, as it had existed in his mind and passions. He felt as if he had known them all, those strange and terrible figures who had traversed the great theater of the world, making sin something so marvelous and evil something so subtle. It seemed to him that, in some mysterious way, their lives had also been his own.

tr_translation: On the other hand, just as a person has ancestors from their lineage, they also have ancestors in the literary world who, in terms of type and disposition, are closer to them than the others, and one could more distinctly perceive their influence. Sometimes it seemed to Dorian as if the entirety of human history consisted solely of his own biography: with its situations and actions, not as he lived them, but as his imagination created them for him, as he envisioned them in his mind and passions. It felt as though he had known all those different, formidable individuals who had passed through the world stage; those who made sin so magnificent and evil so mysterious. It was as if their lives in the past â€“ how, it is unknown â€“ were his own life.

vi_translation: But people have ancestors in literature just as in lineage, perhaps many of these literary ancestors are even closer in type and temperament, and certainly have an influence that we can perceive more perfectly. There are times when Dorian Gray feels that all of history is merely the record of his own life, not as he lives it through actions and circumstances, but as his imagination has created it for him, as it exists in his mind and passions. He feels that he has known all of them, those terrible and strange characters who have passed through the stage of the world and made sin so marvelous, and evil so full of subtlety. He feels as if, in some mysterious way, their lives have become his own.

en: It is said that passion makes one think in a circle. Certainly with hideous iteration the bitten lips of Dorian Gray shaped and reshaped those subtle words that dealt with soul and sense, till he had found in them the full expression, as it were, of his mood, and justified, by intellectual approval, passions that without such justification would still have dominated his temper. From cell to cell of his brain crept the one thought; and the wild desire to live, most terrible of all manâ€™s appetites, quickened into force each trembling nerve and fibre. Ugliness that had once been hateful to him because it made things real, became dear to him now for that very reason. Ugliness was the one reality. The coarse brawl, the loathsome den, the crude violence of disordered life, the very vileness of thief and outcast, were more vivid, in their intense actuality of impression, than all the gracious shapes of art, the dreamy shadows of song. They were what he needed for forgetfulness. In three days he would be free.
es: Se dice que la pasiÃ³n hace que se piense en cÃ­rculos. De cÃ©lula en cÃ©lula aquella idea Ãºnica se apoderaba de su cerebro; y el arrebatado deseo de vivir, el mÃ¡s terrible de los apetitos humanos, redoblaba el vigor de cada nervio y mÃºsculo temblorosos. La fealdad que en otro tiempo le habÃ­a parecido odiosa porque hacÃ­a las cosas reales, le resultaba ahora amable por esa misma razÃ³n. La fealdad era la Ãºnica realidad. La trifulca vulgar, el antro repugnante, la violencia brutal de una vida desordenada, la vileza misma del ladrÃ³n y del fuera de la ley, tenÃ­an mÃ¡s vida, creaban una impresiÃ³n de realidad mÃ¡s intensa que todas las elegantes formas del Arte, que las sombras soÃ±adoras de la CanciÃ³n. Eran lo que necesitaba para alcanzar el olvido. En el espacio de tres dÃ­as quedarÃ­a libre.
es_translation: It is said that passion makes one think in circles. And, certainly, the lips that Dorian Gray kept biting formed and reformed, in a dreadful repetition, the subtle words that dealt with the soul and the senses, until he found in them the full expression, so to speak, of his state of mind, and thus justified, by intellectually approving them, passions that without that justification would have dominated his will. From cell to cell that single idea took hold of his brain; and the frantic desire to live, the most terrible of human appetites, redoubled the vigor of every trembling nerve and muscle. The ugliness that had once seemed odious to him because it made things real, now seemed kind to him for that very reason. Ugliness was the only reality. The vulgar brawl, the repugnant den, the brutal violence of a disordered life, the very vileness of the thief and the outlaw, had more life, created a more intense impression of reality than all the elegant forms of Art, than the dreamy shadows of Song. They were what he needed to achieve oblivion. In the span of three days, he would be free.

tr_translation: They say that passion circles a person's thoughts like a ring and brings them back to where they started. Indeed, Dorian, with his gnawed lips, kept repeating those meaningful words about soul and sense like a disgusting chant. So much so that in the end, he began to find a complete explanation of his spiritual state in these words and thus justified his passions with the approval of his mind. But even without this approval, these passions would not withdraw their hands from his being, anyway. This single thought was seeping from one cell in his brain to another, and the mad desire to live, this most dreadful appetite of mankind, was giving strength to every trembling nerve and fiber like sap. Once, he hated ugliness because it added reality to everything, but now he found it close to himself for the same reason. The only reality was ugliness. Vulgar brawls, disgusting slums, the harsh violence of vagrant lives, the baseness of thieves, dogs, and scoundrels, the products of ugliness, were more vivid and distinct than all the beautiful forms that art entered, and all the imaginary shadows that song sang, because of the tangible intensity of the impressions they created. These were the things Dorian needed to forget. In three days, he would be free.

vi_translation: It is rumored that passion makes people think in circles. Indeed, with the monotonous repetition, Dorian Gray's tightly pressed lips kept molding and reshaping those wicked words about the soul and emotions, until he saw in them the full expression, so to speak, of his mood, and justified, with the approval of intelligence, the passions that without such justification would still dominate his mood. From one brain cell to another, a thought sneaked through; and the intense craving for life, the most terrible of all human desires, revived powerfully every nerve and each trembling muscle fiber. The ugliness that he once found repulsive because it brought things back to reality now became dear to him for that very reason. Ugliness was the only reality. The obscene quarrels, the disgusting den, the crude violence of a disordered life, and even the baseness of the street thieves, were more vivid, thanks to their intense impression of reality, than any form of decent Art, the dreamy shadows of Poetry. They were what he needed to forget. He would be free in three days.

en: At the end of the room there was a little staircase, leading to a darkened chamber. As Dorian hurried up its three rickety steps, the heavy odour of opium met him. He heaved a deep breath, and his nostrils quivered with pleasure. When he entered, a young man with smooth yellow hair, who was bending over a lamp lighting a long thin pipe, looked up at him and nodded in a hesitating manner.

en: Dorian strolled along by his side. He was dominated by the carelessness of happiness, by the high indifference of joy.

en: The elder man laughed. â€œThe only horrible thing in the world is ennui, Dorian. That is the one sin for which there is no forgiveness. en: â€œMy dear fellow,â€ said Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows in surprise, â€œI asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lipsâ€”it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.â€
es: â€”Mi querido amigo â€”dijo lord Henry, alzando las cejas en un gesto de sorpresaâ€”, te lo preguntaba porque te creÃ­a capaz de darme una respuesta. Eso es todo. Cuando iba por el Parque este Ãºltimo domingo, me encontrÃ©, cerca de Marble Arch, un grupito de gente mal vestida escuchando a un vulgar predicador callejero. Cuando pasaba por delante, oÃ­ cÃ³mo aquel hombre le gritaba esa pregunta a su pÃºblico. Todo ello me pareciÃ³ bastante dramÃ¡tico. En Londres abundan los efectos curiosos como Ã©se. Un domingo lluvioso, un vulgar cristiano con un impermeable, un cÃ­rculo de blancos rostros enfermizos bajo un techo desigual de paraguas goteantes, y una frase maravillosa lanzada al aire por unos labios histÃ©ricos y una voz chillona..., estuvo bastante bien, a su manera: toda una sugerencia. Se me ocurriÃ³ decirle al profeta que el Arte sÃ­ tiene un alma, pero no el ser humano. Mucho me temo, de todos modos, que no me hubiera entendido.
es_translation: â€”My dear friend â€”said Lord Henry, raising his eyebrows in a gesture of surpriseâ€”, I asked you because I thought you capable of giving me an answer. That's all. When I was walking through the Park this past Sunday, I came across, near Marble Arch, a small group of poorly dressed people listening to a vulgar street preacher. As I was passing by, I heard that man shouting that question to his audience. It all seemed quite dramatic to me. London abounds with curious effects like that. A rainy Sunday, a vulgar Christian in a raincoat, a circle of pale sickly faces under an uneven roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase thrown into the air by hysterical lips and a shrill voice... it was quite good, in its own way: quite suggestive. It occurred to me to tell the prophet that Art does have a soul, but not the human being. I'm very much afraid, however, that he wouldn't have understood me.

Sonra tiz, isterik bir sesle havaya fÄ±rlatÄ±lan nefis bir tÃ¼mce... GerÃ§ekten fevkaladeydi kendi Ã§apÄ±nda, eni konu etkiliyordu insanÄ±. O peygamber geÃ§inen vaize sÃ¶ylemek geldi iÃ§imden: SanatÄ±n ruhu var ama insanÄ±n ruhu yoktur, diye. Ama benim ne demek istediÄŸimi anlamayacaktÄ±, nasÄ±lsa.
tr_translation: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows in surprise and replied, "My dear, I asked because I thought you might be able to inform me." "That's all. Last Sunday, I was passing through the park; near the Marble Arch, a group of shabbily dressed men had stopped and were listening to a scruffy street preacher. As I passed by, I heard the fellow shouting this question to his listeners. It struck me as quite dramatic. Our London is indeed very rich in such strange scenes. A rainy Sunday, a scruffy Christian in a raincoat, a tattered roof formed by dripping umbrellas, and pale white faces gathered underneath... Then a splendid sentence thrown into the air in a shrill, hysterical voice... It was truly extraordinary in its own way, quite affecting. I felt like telling that so-called prophet: Art has a soul, but man does not. But he wouldn't have understood what I meant, anyway."

vi_translation: â€œMy dear friend,â€ Lord Henry said, raising an eyebrow in surprise, â€œI asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That's all. Last Sunday, I was passing through the Park, and near the Marble Arch, there was a small group of haggard-looking people listening to some mediocre street preacher. As I walked by, I heard him shout that question to his audience. It caught my attention because it was quite dramatic. London is very rich in such strange impressions. A rainy Sunday, a coarse Christian zealot in a raincoat, a circle of pale, sickly faces under the arch bobbing from waterlogged umbrellas, and a soul-stirring proclamation thrown into the air by frenzied, shrill lips â€” it was truly quite wonderful in its own way, a real suggestion. I thought about telling that prophet that Art has a soul, but man does not. I fear, however, that he might not have understood me.â€
